<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 120, 377, 144]]<|/det|> # Cambridge IGCSE™ <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 170, 193, 200]]<|/det|> CANDIDATE NAME <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 222, 168, 250]]<|/det|> CENTRE NUMBER <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[210, 210, 422, 258]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[619, 220, 720, 250]]<|/det|> CANDIDATE NUMBER <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[735, 210, 903, 258]]<|/det|> <|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 277, 176, 292]]<|/det|> ## PHYSICS <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 277, 904, 292]]<|/det|> 0625/52 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 301, 259, 316]]<|/det|> Paper 5 Practical Test <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[770, 301, 904, 316]]<|/det|> May/June 2025 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[760, 325, 904, 340]]<|/det|> 1 hour 15 minutes <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 355, 393, 370]]<|/det|> You must answer on the question paper. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 700, 400]]<|/det|> You will need: The materials and apparatus listed in the confidential instructions <|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 221, 432]]<|/det|> ## INSTRUCTIONS <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 434, 805, 558]]<|/det|> INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.- You should show all your working and use appropriate units. <|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 588, 212, 601]]<|/det|> ## INFORMATION <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 604, 728, 635]]<|/det|> INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 40.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ]. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[710, 645, 904, 840]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 94, 88]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 756, 88]]<|/det|> In this experiment, you will determine the internal diameter \(d\) of a boiling tube. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 103, 841, 120]]<|/det|> You are provided with an empty boiling tube held vertically in the clamp of a retort stand. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 135, 530, 151]]<|/det|> The apparatus is assembled as shown in Fig. 1.1. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[285, 163, 707, 406]]<|/det|> <|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[465, 424, 533, 441]]<|/det|> 
Fig. 1.1

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 456, 148, 473]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 456, 828, 472]]<|/det|>
· Add water from the beaker to the measuring cylinder up to the \(100 \text{cm}^3\) mark.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 486, 918, 520]]<|/det|>
· Add water from the measuring cylinder to the boiling tube until the boiling tube is approximately one-sixth full.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 535, 180, 552]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 535, 918, 566]]<|/det|>
Measure the height \(h\) of the water in the boiling tube in centimetres to the nearest millimetre.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 580, 572, 596]]<|/det|>
Record your result in the top row of Table 1.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 580, 920, 597]]<|/det|>
[1]

<|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 641, 848, 808]]<|/det|>

\(h/\text {cm}\)\(R/\text {cm}^{3}\)\(V/\text {cm}^{3}\)


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 820, 183, 838]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 820, 841, 836]]<|/det|>
Take the reading \(R\) of the volume of water remaining in the measuring cylinder.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 851, 585, 867]]<|/det|>
Record your answer in the top row of Table 1.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 851, 920, 868]]<|/det|>
[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 146, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 73, 180, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[233, 73, 917, 107]]<|/det|>
Add approximately a further \(10 \text{cm}^3\) of water from the measuring cylinder into the boiling tube.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 120, 917, 152]]<|/det|>
• Measure the new height \(h\) of the water in the boiling tube and the reading \(R\) of the water remaining in the measuring cylinder.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 165, 615, 183]]<|/det|>
Record your results in the second row of Table 1.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 165, 920, 183]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 197, 180, 215]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 197, 920, 215]]<|/det|>
Repeat (b)(i) three more times, so that you have five sets of readings in Table 1.1. [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 228, 144, 246]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 228, 920, 260]]<|/det|>
Calculate the volume \(V\) of water poured into the boiling tube for each different height \(h\) of water.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 274, 456, 292]]<|/det|>
Use the equation \(V = (100 \text{cm}^3 - R)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 305, 425, 322]]<|/det|>
Record your results in Table 1.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 351, 920, 370]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 383, 148, 400]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 383, 873, 400]]<|/det|>
Plot a graph of \(V / \text{cm}^3\) (\(y\)-axis) against \(h / \text{cm}\) (\(x\)-axis). Start your axes at the origin \((0, 0)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 414, 399, 431]]<|/det|>
Draw the best-fit straight line.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[57, 443, 939, 920]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 907, 920, 925]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 73, 146, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(e)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 73, 918, 107]]<|/det|>
Determine the gradient \(G\) of your line. Show all working and indicate on the graph the values you use.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 179, 917, 197]]<|/det|>
<form>G = ................................................................................. [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 211, 144, 230]]<|/det|>
<label>(f)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 211, 181, 230]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 211, 918, 230]]<|/det|>
The internal diameter \(d\) of a cylinder is given by the equation \(d = k\sqrt{G}\) , where \(k = 1.13 \text{cm}\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 242, 453, 260]]<|/det|>
Calculate \(d\) for the boiling tube.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[554, 320, 917, 338]]<|/det|>
<form>d = ................................................................. cm [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 352, 181, 370]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 352, 795, 370]]<|/det|>
Suggest one reason why your calculated value for \(d\) is only approximate.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[880, 412, 920, 431]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 444, 148, 463]]<|/det|>
<label>(g)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 444, 920, 477]]<|/det|>
It is important to avoid line-of-sight (parallax) errors when reading the scale of the measuring cylinder.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 490, 692, 508]]<|/det|>
Describe how such errors are avoided. You may draw a diagram.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[834, 720, 920, 738]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[833, 721, 920, 740]]<|/det|>
<mark>[12]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 94, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 705, 90]]<|/det|>
In this experiment, you will investigate a light-dependent resistor (LDR).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 104, 918, 136]]<|/det|>
You are provided with a series circuit consisting of a power supply, a switch, a \(470\Omega\) resistor and an LDR.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 151, 146, 168]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 151, 918, 183]]<|/det|>
Draw a circuit diagram of the circuit that has been set up for you. Choose symbols from the list in Fig. 2.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[198, 195, 790, 345]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[465, 361, 533, 378]]<|/det|>
<pre>Fig. 2.1

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 617, 920, 635]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 647, 146, 666]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 647, 180, 666]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[232, 648, 376, 664]]<|/det|>
Close the switch.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[232, 661, 620, 679]]<|/det|>
Connect the voltmeter between points X and Y.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 694, 475, 711]]<|/det|>
Record the voltmeter reading \(V_{XY}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[534, 723, 920, 740]]<|/det|>
<form>V_{XY} = .................................................................... V [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 753, 180, 772]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[190, 755, 622, 772]]<|/det|>
Connect the voltmeter between points Y and Z.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 787, 477, 804]]<|/det|>
Record the voltmeter reading \(V_{YZ}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[534, 815, 920, 833]]<|/det|>
<form>V_{YZ} = .................................................................... V

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 847, 374, 864]]<|/det|>
Open the switch.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 847, 920, 864]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 146, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 73, 180, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 73, 677, 90]]<|/det|>
The current \(I\) in the circuit is calculated using the equation:

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[460, 93, 536, 123]]<|/det|>
\[I = \frac{V_{XY}}{R},\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 135, 340, 151]]<|/det|>
where \(R = 470 \Omega\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 165, 697, 182]]<|/det|>
Use your voltmeter reading in (b)(i) to calculate the current \(I\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[556, 281, 920, 298]]<|/det|>
<form>I = .................................................................... A [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 313, 181, 331]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 313, 680, 330]]<|/det|>
The resistance of the LDR is calculated using the equation:

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[458, 333, 539, 364]]<|/det|>
\[R = \frac{V_{YZ}}{I}.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 375, 826, 392]]<|/det|>
Use your voltmeter reading in (b)(ii) to calculate the resistance \(R\) of the LDR.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 490, 920, 507]]<|/det|>
<form>R = ............................................................ $\Omega$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 522, 148, 540]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 522, 573, 539]]<|/det|>
• Disconnect the voltmeter from points Y and Z.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 539, 542, 555]]<|/det|>
• Place the piece of card on top of the LDR.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 570, 482, 585]]<|/det|>
Repeat the measurements made in (b).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[534, 613, 920, 630]]<|/det|>
<form>V_{XY} = .................................................................... V

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[534, 645, 920, 662]]<|/det|>
<form>V_{YZ} = .................................................................... V

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 662, 920, 680]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 694, 146, 711]]<|/det|>
<label>(e)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[198, 694, 717, 710]]<|/det|>
Ensure that the voltmeter is connected between points Y and Z.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[198, 710, 359, 725]]<|/det|>
Close the switch.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[200, 725, 645, 740]]<|/det|>
Hold the card horizontally about 50 cm above the LDR.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[200, 740, 770, 756]]<|/det|>
Slowly move the card towards the LDR until it rests on top of the LDR.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[200, 756, 690, 771]]<|/det|>
Observe the reading on the voltmeter as you move the card.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 785, 390, 802]]<|/det|>
<pre>Describe your observations.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 880, 920, 898]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 144, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(f)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 72, 750, 90]]<|/det|>
When the LDR is covered by the card, the current in the circuit changes.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 104, 918, 136]]<|/det|>
Use your results in **(b)** and **(d)** to state how this change in current affects the total potential difference \((V_{XY} + V_{YZ})\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[870, 228, 917, 246]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 259, 148, 276]]<|/det|>
<label>(g)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 259, 918, 291]]<|/det|>
Compare your value for the potential difference \(V_{YZ}\) across the LDR in bright light in **(b)** with the value for the potential difference \(V_{YZ}\) across the LDR in the dark in **(d)**.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 305, 918, 336]]<|/det|>
Suggest what causes the change in the readings as the intensity of the light reaching the LDR decreases.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[833, 412, 920, 429]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 10]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 94, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 760, 90]]<|/det|>
In this experiment, you will investigate the image formed by a converging lens.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 104, 260, 120]]<|/det|>
Refer to Fig. 3.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[171, 135, 825, 316]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[465, 341, 532, 358]]<|/det|>
<pre>Fig. 3.1

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 373, 146, 392]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 373, 180, 392]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[232, 373, 397, 390]]<|/det|>
Switch on the lamp.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 388, 918, 420]]<|/det|>
Place the screen a distance \(D = 80.0 \text{cm}\) from the illuminated object (the triangular hole in the card).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 419, 605, 435]]<|/det|>
Place the lens close to the illuminated object.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[190, 434, 918, 465]]<|/det|>
Move the lens away from the illuminated object until a magnified, sharp image of the illuminated object is formed on the screen.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[190, 464, 918, 495]]<|/det|>
Do not move the illuminated object, the lens or the screen after this image position is found.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 510, 918, 542]]<|/det|>
Measure, to the nearest \(0.1 \text{cm}\) , the object distance \(x_{1}\) from the centre of the lens to the illuminated object.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[547, 556, 918, 573]]<|/det|>
<form>x_{1} = ............................................................ $cm$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[920, 556, 920, 573]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 588, 180, 606]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 588, 918, 619]]<|/det|>
Continue to move the lens away from the illuminated object until a diminished, sharp image of the illuminated object is formed on the screen.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 635, 918, 666]]<|/det|>
Measure, to the nearest \(0.1 \text{cm}\) , the object distance \(y_{1}\) from the centre of the lens to the illuminated object.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[547, 680, 918, 697]]<|/det|>
<form>y_{1} = ............................................................ $cm$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[920, 680, 920, 697]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 711, 180, 730]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 712, 463, 730]]<|/det|>
Calculate the value \(d = (y_{1} - x_{1})\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[552, 774, 920, 790]]<|/det|>
<form>d = ............................................................ $cm$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[920, 774, 920, 790]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 148, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 72, 666, 90]]<|/det|>
The focal length \(f\) of the lens can be found using the equation:

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[437, 95, 559, 128]]<|/det|>
\[f = \frac{(D^2 - d^2)}{4D}.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 138, 918, 171]]<|/det|>
Use the value of \(D\) from (a)(i) and \(d\) from (a)(iii) to calculate a value \(f_{1}\) for the focal length of the lens.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 184, 808, 201]]<|/det|>
Give your answer to a suitable number of significant figures for this experiment.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 276, 918, 294]]<|/det|>
<form>f_1 = ............................................................ $cm$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 278, 918, 295]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 308, 144, 326]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 308, 180, 326]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 308, 918, 341]]<|/det|>
Repeat the procedure in (a)(i), (a)(ii) and (a)(iii) for an illuminated object to screen distance \(D = 100.0 \text{cm}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 355, 484, 371]]<|/det|>
Record your values of \(x_{2},\) \(y_{2}\) and \(d.\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[546, 384, 918, 402]]<|/det|>
<form>x_{2} = ............................................................ $cm$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[546, 416, 918, 434]]<|/det|>
<form>y_{2} = ............................................................ $cm$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 447, 918, 464]]<|/det|>
<form>d = ............................................................ $cm$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 464, 920, 481]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 494, 181, 513]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 494, 918, 527]]<|/det|>
Calculate a second value \(f_{2}\) for the focal length of the lens using the equation in (b) and your values in (c)(i).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 616, 918, 634]]<|/det|>
<form>f_{2} = ............................................................ $cm$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 618, 920, 636]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 648, 148, 666]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 648, 918, 680]]<|/det|>
Two quantities can be considered to be equal within the limits of experimental accuracy if their values are within \(10\%\) of each other.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 694, 835, 711]]<|/det|>
State whether your values of \(f_{1}\) and \(f_{2}\) from (b) and (c)(ii) can be considered equal.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 725, 502, 742]]<|/det|>
Support your statement with a calculation.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 879, 915, 896]]<|/det|>
statement ....................................................................................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 925, 920, 944]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 144, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(e)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 180, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 72, 917, 106]]<|/det|>
State one technique you use when doing the experiment to ensure that the image on the screen is focused as clearly as possible.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[880, 180, 917, 199]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 211, 180, 230]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 211, 626, 230]]<|/det|>
This experiment is usually done in a darkened room.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 242, 744, 260]]<|/det|>
Explain how this makes it easier to see when the image is in focus.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[833, 335, 920, 352]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 11]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 92, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 72, 772, 90]]<|/det|>
Hot water is poured into a glass beaker and allowed to cool down for 5 minutes.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 104, 917, 136]]<|/det|>
Plan an experiment to investigate whether the rate of cooling of the hot water depends upon the initial temperature of the hot water.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 150, 687, 167]]<|/det|>
The rate of cooling of the water can be calculated using the equation:

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[319, 171, 680, 205]]<|/det|>
\[\text{rate of cooling} = \frac{\text{decrease in temperature}}{\text{time taken}}.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 212, 304, 228]]<|/det|>
You are provided with:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 243, 340, 258]]<|/det|>
· a supply of cold water

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 260, 290, 273]]<|/det|>
· an electric kettle

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 275, 351, 289]]<|/det|>
· a \(250cm^3\) glass beaker

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 291, 334, 305]]<|/det|>
· a measuring cylinder.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 320, 564, 336]]<|/det|>
You may use any other common laboratory apparatus.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 351, 484, 366]]<|/det|>
You are **not** required to do this investigation.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 381, 292, 396]]<|/det|>
In your plan, include:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 412, 392, 427]]<|/det|>
· any other apparatus needed

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 428, 917, 459]]<|/det|>
· a brief description of the method, including what you will measure and how you will make sure your measurements are accurate

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 460, 392, 474]]<|/det|>
· the variables you will control

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 475, 917, 505]]<|/det|>
· a results table to record your measurements (you are **not** required to enter any readings in the table)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 507, 615, 522]]<|/det|>
· how you will process your results to reach a conclusion.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 537, 418, 552]]<|/det|>
You may include a labelled diagram.
